text:
I'm shocked why people aren't using ChatGPT to get their dream job. 

Use this cheatsheet to get the job you're looking for: 

Check and Save these - 20 powerful prompts to accelerate your job search!

 Prompt 1: ATS-Friendly Resume Formatting

"Format my resume to be ATS-friendly for a [specific role/industry] position, focusing on keyword optimization, clear structure, and measurable achievements."

 Prompt 2: Crafting an Engaging LinkedIn Headline

"Create a LinkedIn headline that grabs the attention of recruiters in [industry/role], incorporating keywords that align with my expertise and career goals."

 Prompt 3: Networking Message for Informational Interview

"Write a LinkedIn message requesting an informational interview with [person's name], a [position title] at [company], to learn more about their career journey and the company's culture."

 Prompt 4: Job-Specific LinkedIn Profile Summary

"Revamp my LinkedIn summary to align with positions in [industry/role], highlighting my most relevant achievements, skills, and professional goals to attract recruiters."

 Prompt 5: Referral Request Message

"Draft a LinkedIn message to request a referral from a connection who works at [company] for a [specific position], highlighting my interest & relevant experience."

 Prompt 6: Creating a Strong Personal Brand Statement

"Develop a concise personal brand statement that communicates my value in [specific industry/role], emphasizing key skills & what sets me apart."

 Prompt 7: LinkedIn Activity to Attract Recruiters

"Suggest LinkedIn post ideas I can share weekly that showcase my knowledge & expertise in [industry/field] to increase profile visibility & attract recruiters."

 Prompt 8: Cold Email to Hiring Manager

"Compose a cold email to introduce myself as a potential candidate for [position] at [company], briefly summarizing my relevant skills and interest in the role."

 Prompt 9: Professional Summary for Job Boards

"Write a professional summary for my profiles on job boards (e.g., Indeed, Glassdoor) that attracts recruiters in [industry] & highlights my top skills and experience."

 Prompt 10: Skills Section Optimization on LinkedIn

"Suggest keywords and skills to add to my LinkedIn profile's skills section to increase visibility in searches for [industry/role] professionals."

 Prompt 11: Relevant Achievements in Cover Letter

"Write a short paragraph for my cover letter, detailing a key achievement in [specific area, e.g., sales, project management] that demonstrates my impact & relevance for [position]."

For more useful prompts, do checkout Carousel 

Which of these prompts will you try first?

Comment below - I'm curious what stage you're at in your job hunt!

65 Toughest Interview Questions You should must know in 2025

This Pdf contains 65+ interview questions & provides you with helpful tips on answering each & every one.

Ready to rock your interviews? Check out these easy tips:

1 Research, Research, Research: Dive deep into the company's background, culture, values & recent wins. Tailor your responses to showcase your alignment with their mission

2 Practice Makes Perfect: Fine-tune your answers by practicing with a friend or in front of a mirror. This helps you articulate your thoughts clearly & confidently

3 Know Your Strengths: Identify your key strengths & unique selling points. Showcase how they bring value to the role & the organization

4 Be STAR-Ready: Structure your answers using the STAR method for behavioral questions. Provide concise yet comprehensive responses showcasing your problem-solving skills

5 Questions Are a Two-Way Street: Prepare thoughtful questions about the company, team dynamics & the role. Demonstrate your genuine interest & assess if it's the right fit for you

6 Dress the Part: Align your attire with the company's culture. When you look confident, you'll feel confident & make a positive first impression

7 Body Language Matters: Convey confidence & enthusiasm through positive body language - eye contact, a firm handshake & sitting up straight

8 Highlight Your Achievements: Use specific examples to showcase your accomplishments & how you can contribute to the company's success

9 Stay Calm Under Pressure: Take deep breaths, stay composed & let your true personality shine through

10 Send a Thank-You Note: After the interview, express gratitude & reiterate your interest in the role through a personalized thank-you note

Whether you've got a job interview tomorrow, or you just want to freshen up on some common interview questions, this is the perfect resource for you

Each question & piece of content in this book is short, sweet & to the point. It includes some of the most common interview questions, as well as ones I'm sure you've never even thought of

99% of SQL Interviews Repeat the Same Questions.
Here's how to master them once & for all 

I still remember my first SQL test.

I had revised everything -- SELECT, JOINS, even indexing.
But when the interviewer asked:

 Can you write a query to get the 3rd highest salary without using TOP or LIMIT?

...I blanked out completely. 

That's when it hit me:
 Interviews aren't about random questions -- they recycle the same patterns again & again.

So instead of trying to learn everything, I compiled the Most Frequently Asked SQL Interview Questions -- the ones you will face in 8/10 interviews.

Here's a quick preview 

 Top SQL Interview Questions & Solutions

1 Find the 2nd highest salary

SELECT MAX(salary) 
FROM employees 
WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees);

2 Find duplicates in a table

SELECT name, COUNT(*) 
FROM employees 
GROUP BY name 
HAVING COUNT(*) > 1;

3 Retrieve the top 3 salaries

SELECT DISTINCT salary 
FROM employees 
ORDER BY salary DESC 
LIMIT 3;

4 Difference between DELETE vs TRUNCATE

DELETE  Removes rows (rollback possible)

TRUNCATE  Resets table (faster, no rollback)

5 Find employees who don't have a manager

SELECT * 
FROM employees 
WHERE manager_id IS NULL;

 Bonus for You
Along with the PDF of 100+ SQL Interview Questions, I've added 9 Free SQL resources I personally use:

This Pdf contains 35+ HR interview questions & provides you with helpful tips on answering each & every one.

Ready to rock your interviews? Check out these easy tips:

1Research, Research, Research: Dive deep into the company's background, culture, values & recent wins. Tailor your responses to showcase your alignment with their mission

2Practice Makes Perfect: Fine-tune your answers by practicing with a friend or in front of a mirror. This helps you articulate your thoughts clearly & confidently

3Know Your Strengths: Identify your key strengths & unique selling points. Showcase how they bring value to the role & the organization

4Be STAR-Ready: Structure your answers using the STAR method for behavioral questions. Provide concise yet comprehensive responses showcasing your problem-solving skills

5Questions Are a Two-Way Street: Prepare thoughtful questions about the company, team dynamics & the role. Demonstrate your genuine interest & assess if it's the right fit for you

6Dress the Part: Align your attire with the company's culture. When you look confident, you'll feel confident & make a positive first impression

7Body Language Matters: Convey confidence & enthusiasm through positive body language - eye contact, a firm handshake & sitting up straight

8Highlight Your Achievements: Use specific examples to showcase your accomplishments & how you can contribute to the company's success

9Stay Calm Under Pressure: Take deep breaths, stay composed & let your true personality shine through

10Send a Thank-You Note: After the interview, express gratitude & reiterate your interest in the role through a personalized thank-you note

I'll never forget the excitement of receiving my first salary. That feeling of freedom, of finally being independent. I thought I could take on the world.

But reality entered quickly:
Rent, groceries, travel... and then came the biggest expense--furniture.

Bed + mattress: 25,000+
Fridge: 15,000+
Wardrobe: 10,000+
That's more than 50,000 gone instantly.

Half my salary would have vanished before I even started living.

That's when I discovered renting. With RentoMojo, I got everything--bed, fridge, table--at 1/10th the upfront cost. My flat was set up within 48 hours, and I could save my salary for experiences instead of EMIs.

Your first salary should be about creating memories, not paying bills.

PS: Thank you RentoMojo for helping me hold on to my first-salary glow a little longer.

From "What's SELECT?" to "I Can Tackle Any SQL Query" -- The Beginner's Roadmap

When I first opened SQL, I thought:
"Just learn SELECT * FROM table ...and I'm good to go."

But the first time I looked at a real dataset?
I froze. 

 Which columns do I need?
 Why is this JOIN giving me duplicates?
 How do I even calculate running totals?

That's when I realised:
 SQL is not about memorising commands.
It's about learning them in the right sequence -- layer by layer.

So here's the SQL Beginner's Roadmap I wish I had 

Phase 1 -- Foundations (Learn to Walk First )

 SELECT, WHERE, ORDER BY

 Basic Aggregates: COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX

 GROUP BY + HAVING

 You'll use these 80% of the time in real jobs.

Phase 2 -- Relationships (Talking Across Tables )

 INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, FULL JOIN

 Self JOIN (surprisingly common in interviews!)

 UNION vs UNION ALL

 Core skill: Combine tables without breaking the logic.

Phase 3 -- Smarter Queries (Thinking Like an Analyst )

 CASE WHEN conditions

 Handling NULLs (COALESCE, ISNULL)

 Filtering with multiple conditions

 Real-world use: Categorise, clean, and validate messy data.

Phase 4 -- Analytical SQL (The Level-Up )

 Window Functions: ROW_NUMBER, RANK, DENSE_RANK

 PARTITION BY + ORDER BY

 LAG & LEAD for trends

 This is where you stand out in interviews.

Phase 5 -- Building Complex Solutions (The Fun Stuff )

CTEs (step-by-step queries)

Subqueries (correlated & non-correlated)

Combining multiple transformations

 Interview Pattern: Break one huge task into smaller, cleaner queries.

Phase 6 -- Scaling & Optimisation (Pro Mode )

 Index basics (clustered vs non-clustered)

 Query optimisation tricks

 Avoiding SELECT *

 The difference between a beginner & a pro = performance thinking.

 Pro Tip for Beginners:
 Don't just memorise queries. Practice thinking through problems
 Write 3 different solutions to the same question -- it trains flexibility under pressure

Struggling With SQL Interviews? You're Not Alone.
And here's what I wish I knew earlier 

My first SQL interview was a disaster.
I had memorized joins, functions, even indexes...
But the moment they asked:

 "Can you find duplicates in a table without using DISTINCT?"

...I froze. 

That's when I realized something important:
 Interviews don't care if you've read every SQL tutorial.
 They care if you can solve practical, real-world problems.

So I started tracking the most common SQL questions asked in interviews -- from FAANG to startups.
And patterns began to emerge.

So I built this for all the learners like me 

 100 Most-Asked SQL Interview Questions -- in One Free PDF

 From basics to advanced
 Real-world query challenges
 Problem-solving patterns
 Performance tips + optimization hacks
 Questions asked by top tech companies

 Who is this for?

 Freshers preparing for placements
 Professionals switching careers
 Data Analysts & Engineers brushing up before interviews

Failed an SQL interview even though you knew the basics?
You're not alone.

Here's the hard truth:
 SQL interviews at top companies aren't about SELECT or JOIN.
 They're about advanced problem-solving under pressure.

I learned this the hard way.

 In one interview, I was asked:
"Detect salary outliers in each department using window functions."

My mind went blank. 
Not because I didn't know SQL...
But because I hadn't practiced advanced patterns.

That's when I realized:
 To clear SQL interviews, you must go beyond syntax & master the next-level questions.

So I compiled some real Advanced SQL Questions asked at top companies 

 American Express
 Amazon
 Uber
 Flipkart
 HCL, Wipro & more

 Advanced SQL Interview Questions

1 Find the top 3 customers by monthly spend (across all months).
2 Detect duplicate transactions within 5 minutes for the same user.
3 Fetch employees earning above department average (with CTE).
4 Write a query to calculate running total + moving average of sales.
5 Identify salary outliers using standard deviation/window functions.
6 Delete duplicate rows but keep only the earliest record.
7 Compare employee salary with company average using subquery.
8 Customers who bought in Jan but NOT in Feb (anti-join challenge).

 Who needs this?

 Data Analysts preparing for advanced interviews
 Engineers switching to data roles
 Professionals brushing up before FAANG / Big 4 interviews

 Daily Tip: Practice ONE advanced SQL question a day.
Classify it  Window Functions, Aggregations, Joins, CTEs, Optimization.
Patterns > Memorization.

That's how you go from:
"I freeze in advanced SQL interviews."
 to 
"Throw me your toughest question."
